यस्मिन्सर्वाणि भूतानि आत्मैवाभूद्विजानतः ।
तत्र को मोहः कः शोक एकत्वमनुपश्यतः ॥ ७ ॥

translations.text: When to the knower all beings have verily become the Self, then what delusion and what sorrow can there be for that seer of oneness?
When, to one who knows, all beings have become one with his own Self, then what delusion and what sorrow can be for that seer of oneness?

bhashya.sanskrit: यस्मिन्सर्वाणि भूतानि यस्मिन् काले यथोक्तात्मनि वा, तान्येव भूतानि सर्वाणि परमार्थात्मदर्शनात् आत्मैवाभूत् आत्मैव संवृत्तः परमार्थवस्तु विजानतः, तत्र तस्मिन्काले तत्रात्मनि वा, को मोहः कः शोकः । शोकश्च मोहश्च कामकर्मबीजमजानतो भवति, न त्वात्मैकत्वं विशुद्धं गगनोपमं पश्यतः । को मोहः कः शोक इति शोकमोहयोरविद्याकार्ययोराक्षेपेणासम्भवप्रकाशनात् सकारणस्य संसारस्यात्यन्तमेवोच्छेदः प्रदर्शितो भवति ॥
keyPoints: When all beings have become the Self alone for the knower of reality
Either at that time (of realization) or in that Self (as locus)
What delusion and what sorrow can there be?
Sorrow and delusion arise from ignorance, being the seeds of desire and karma
They do not exist for one who sees the pure oneness of Self, like space
By rhetorically denying delusion and sorrow (effects of ignorance), the complete cessation of saṃsāra with its cause is demonstrated
This shows the total annihilation of the entire causal chain of saṃsāra
bhashya.notes: This mantra is the culmination of mantras 5 and 6, emphasizing the complete freedom from all suffering that comes from Self-knowledge. Śaṅkara Bhagavadpāda's commentary is particularly significant here: by rhetorically asking 'what delusion? what sorrow?' (ko mohaḥ kaḥ śokaḥ), the mantra negates not just these two but their entire causal chain. Since moha and śoka are effects of avidyā and are themselves the seeds (bīja) of desire and action, their impossibility means the total destruction (atyantam eva ucchedaḥ) of saṃsāra with all its causes. The comparison to space (gaganopama) emphasizes the Self's pure, undivided, all-pervading nature.

centralTeaching: For the one who has realized the oneness of the Self - seeing all beings as the Self alone - there can be no delusion or sorrow whatsoever. Since moha and śoka are products of ignorance and are themselves the seeds of desire and karma, their impossibility in Self-knowledge demonstrates the complete and permanent cessation of saṃsāra along with its entire causal chain.

coreConcepts.definition: Vision of oneness; seeing all beings as the one non-dual Self without any differentiation
Delusion, confusion; the fundamental ignorance about the nature of reality that leads to misidentification
Sorrow, grief; the suffering that arises from attachment and loss, rooted in ignorance
Seeds of desire and action; moha and śoka function as the causal factors that generate desire and karma
Like space; the Self compared to space in its purity, undividedness, and all-pervasiveness
Complete cessation of saṃsāra; the total destruction of the cycle of birth and death along with all its causes

relatedVerses.note: This mantra elaborates on the result described in mantra 6 - seeing oneness leads to freedom from all negative emotions
Describes how sorrow belongs only to one who sees duality
The wise do not grieve for either the living or the dead
One who is established in Brahman neither grieves nor desires
